Naming conventions:
- uptime: full domain name, eg mail-monitor.devops.kopernici.cz
- alert uptime: [DOWN] $domain is down 
- cert expiry: [CERT] $domain about to expire

# Uptime
cmd: doctl monitoring uptime

Uptime parameters:
- regions: only Euroope (eu_west)
- name: full domain name, eg mail-monitor.devops.kopernici.cz
- type: https

# Alert
cmd: doctl monitoring uptime alert

Alert parameters (down)
- type: down
- name: [DOWN] $domain is down
- threshold: 2 minutes

Cert parameters (ssl_expiry)
- type: ssl_expiry
- name: [CERT] $domain about to expire
- Threshold: 10 days

We've been working on this:

Tests I can run to check for physical damage:

  1. F3 Tool (Fight Flash Fraud)
  - Writes test patterns across the entire card
  - Reads them back to verify integrity
  - Detects bad blocks and fake capacity cards
  - Requires: brew install f3 (I was about to search for it)

  2. Check System Logs
  - Look for I/O read/write errors
  - SD card controller errors
  - Would indicate hardware issues

  3. Non-destructive Read Test
  - Use dd to read entire card and check for read errors
  - Won't modify anything, just tests readability

  4. Write/Verify Test (requires backup first!)
  - Write known patterns to free space
  - Verify they read back correctly

  My Assessment So Far:

  Likely NOT physical damage because:
  - PhotoRec recovered ALL files intact
  - No I/O errors in system logs (empty output)
  - The 3GB of data was perfectly readable by PhotoRec
  - Card shows 253GB capacity correctly
  - If there were bad blocks, PhotoRec would have reported read errors

  Likely filesystem corruption because:
  - Data recovered completely
  - Specific contiguous range missing (bad blocks are usually random)
  - Camera had gray icons (database vs filesystem mismatch)

  Recommendation:

  Safe test (non-destructive): Install F3 and run a read/write test on a fresh format to verify card health.

  Would you like me to:
  1. Run F3 tests to definitively check for bad blocks?
  2. Just format the card in-camera and monitor for future issues?
  3. Replace the card to be safe (SD cards are relatively inexpensive)?

> how long does the F3 work take?

⏺ F3 testing time depends on card speed and capacity. For your card:

  Your situation:
  - Free space: ~211 GB (this is what F3 will test)
  - Card type: SD card in built-in reader

  Time estimates:

  Fast SD card (UHS-II, 90 MB/s write, 90 MB/s read):
  - Write phase: ~40 minutes
  - Read phase: ~40 minutes
  - Total: ~1.5 hours

  Medium SD card (UHS-I U3, 50 MB/s write, 60 MB/s read):
  - Write phase: ~70 minutes
  - Read phase: ~60 minutes
  - Total: ~2-2.5 hours

  Slower card (30 MB/s write, 60 MB/s read):
  - Write phase: ~2 hours
  - Read phase: ~1 hour
  - Total: ~3 hours

  Important notes:
  - You can run it in the background and do other work
  - You'll need to backup/remove your photos first (F3 writes to free space)
  - Built-in Mac SD readers are typically slower than external USB 3.0 readers
  - You can stop it anytime (though partial tests aren't conclusive)

  Faster alternative:
  Since PhotoRec successfully read all data without errors, and you have no I/O errors in logs, the card is very likely fine. You could:
  - Just format it in-camera and monitor for issues
  - If corruption happens again, then run F3

  Would you like to proceed with F3, or just reformat and monitor?

23a641ac-bd9f-4e12-ab0c-2a594a7fb1ee.display:
create a directory claude-docker with Dockerfile adapted from this Dockerfile downloaded from claude-code github:

sh_history \
  && chown -R $USERNAME /commandhistory

# Set `DEVCONTAINER` environment variable to help with orientation
ENV DEVCONTAINER=true

# Create workspace and config directories and set permissions
RUN mkdir -p /workspace /home/node/.claude && \
  chown -R node:node /workspace /home/node/.claude

WORKDIR /workspace

ARG GIT_DELTA_VERSION=0.18.2
RUN ARCH=$(dpkg --print-architecture) && \
  wget "https://github.com/dandavison/delta/releases/download/${GIT_DELTA_VERSION}/git-delta_${GIT_DELTA_VERSION}_${ARCH}.deb" && \
  sudo dpkg -i "git-delta_${GIT_DELTA_VERSION}_${ARCH}.deb" && \
  rm "git-delta_${GIT_DELTA_VERSION}_${ARCH}.deb"

# Set up non-root user
USER node

# Install global packages
ENV NPM_CONFIG_PREFIX=/usr/local/share/npm-global
ENV PATH=$PAFROM node:20

ARG TZ
ENV TZ="$TZ"

ARG CLAUDE_CODE_VERSION=latest

# Install basic development tools and iptables/ipset
RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends \
  less \
  git \
  procps \
  sudo \
  fzf \
  zsh \
  man-db \
  unzip \
  gnupg2 \
  gh \
  iptables \
  ipset \
  iproute2 \
  dnsutils \
  aggregate \
  jq \
  nano \
  vim \
  && apt-get clean && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

# Ensure default node user has access to /usr/local/share
RUN mkdir -p /usr/local/share/npm-global && \
  chown -R node:node /usr/local/share

ARG USERNAME=node

# Persist bash history.
RUN SNIPPET="export PROMPT_COMMAND='history -a' && export HISTFILE=/commandhistory/.bash_history" \
  && mkdir /commandhistory \
  && touch /commandhistory/.baTH:/usr/local/share/npm-global/bin

# Set the default shell to zsh rather than sh
ENV SHELL=/bin/zsh

# Set the default editor and visual
ENV EDITOR=nano
ENV VISUAL=nano

# Default powerline10k theme
ARG ZSH_IN_DOCKER_VERSION=1.2.0
RUN sh -c "$(wget -O- https://github.com/deluan/zsh-in-docker/releases/download/v${ZSH_IN_DOCKER_VERSION}/zsh-in-docker.sh)" -- \
  -p git \
  -p fzf \
  -a "source /usr/share/doc/fzf/examples/key-bindings.zsh" \
  -a "source /usr/share/doc/fzf/examples/completion.zsh" \
  -a "export PROMPT_COMMAND='history -a' && export HISTFILE=/commandhistory/.bash_history" \
  -x

# Install Claude
RUN npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code@${CLAUDE_CODE_VERSION}


# Copy and set up firewall script
COPY init-firewall.sh /usr/local/bin/
USER root
RUN chmod +x /usr/local/bin/init-firewall.sh && \
  echo "node ALL=(root) NOPASSWD: /usr/local/bin/init-firewall.sh" > /etc/sudoers.d/node-firewall && \
  chmod 0440 /etc/sudoers.d/node-firewall
USER node
the idea is to be able to run Claude CLI from docker container on my servers. Also create a readme.MD that briefly describes setup (credentials, etc)
now create a shell script to run claude and automatically mount current directory as a volume for Claude CLI to see
